title: Pollution prevention and control (PPC) permit for air emissions (Scotland)

details.description: If you operate a facility in Scotland which emits substances into the air, you may need a pollution prevention and control (PPC) Part B permit

details.licence_overview:
$! You may need to get a pollution prevention and control (PPC) Part B permit if you operate a facility in Scotland which produces air emissions. $!

Certain commercial activities which produce air emissions are called [Part B activities.](http://www.sepa.org.uk/air/process_industry_regulation/pollution_prevention__control/public_participation_directive/part_b_activities.aspx "part B activities"){:rel="external"} These include:

* dry cleaning
* petrol vapour recovery (PVR)
* cement batching
* roadstone coating

Contact your local [Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) office](http://www.sepa.org.uk/about_us/contacting_sepa/regional_offices.aspx "local SEPA offices"){:rel="external"} to find out if you need a permit.


##Conditions

The permit means you must:

* monitor the emissions from the activity (or activities) and record the results 
* notify SEPA in case of accidental releases and releases above the limits set for your
emissions
* keep certain records that may be inspected by SEPA

^SEPA periodically reviews each of its PPC permits.^

##How to apply

The SEPA website has information on [applying for a PPC Part B permit.](http://www.sepa.org.uk/air/process_industry_regulation/pollution_prevention__control/public_participation_directive/part_b_activities.aspx "PPC part B permit applications"){:rel="external"} 

You will have to pay an application fee. There's also a fee to make major changes to your permit. 

Read 'Pollution Prevention and Control (Scotland) Regulations 2000 - A Practical Guide' for more information.

$D
[Download 'Pollution Prevention and Control (Scotland) Regulations 2000 - A Practical Guide' (PDF, 374KB)](http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/Doc/158532/0042982.pdf "Download 'Pollution Prevention and Control (Scotland) Regulations 2000 - A Practical Guide' (PDF, 374KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Fines and penalties

If you don't get a permit or don't comply with the conditions of your permit, you could be fined up to Â£20,000 and/or be sentenced to 6 months imprisonment.

*[PVR]: petrol vapour recovery 
*[SEPA]: Scottish Environment Protection Agency
*[PPC]: pollution prevention and control
